column1: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from the Democratic Republic of the Congo engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in the Democratic Republic of the Congo?

column6: I am using the current crowd forest of 10% as a baseline. I then increase it by 10% as the current prediction still doesn't factor in the recent outbreak of communal violence between Hema cattle-herders and Lendu farmers in Ituri province. It is estimated that around 160 people were killed in communal clashes between these groups between 7 and 16 June. The security forces don't have the capacity and/or the inclination to prevent an escalation of the crisis. Moreover, around 50,000 were killed in clashes between these groups in the period of 1999-2007 and I believe that this history of deadly clashes makes a serious escalation more likely. While I think that EWP's statistical model overestimates the risk (31%) of a new outbreak because it is affected by data from the Kivus, which should be discounted, I still increase my forecast by further 5% to account for structural risk factors identified by the EWP's statistical model. I admit that increasing by 5% and not by 4% or 6% in both cases is a purely arbitrary decision, but I am very new at this forecasting project and I am still trying to find a more constructive way to think about it.

Relying on news reports over several years, there are *always* people in the DRC being killed by armed groups. I doubt that 2019 will be an exception; an outbreak of peace seems unlikely, but I suppose possible.
Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007
